en: When did you join the company?
Well,
you know, I knew I knew
Dave Lane for many, many years since I was, like, 14 years old.
And, you know, later on, Dave was starting
to make climbing harnesses and I was making,
you know, backpacks and custom clothing and all that sort of thing.
And as, as rock
solid Dave's company was getting set up.
Excuse me. Yeah.
He phoned me and said, oh, you should come and join me
in bringing what you're doing into the mix.
And I said to him, honestly, Dave, you know, I don't think either of us
are even making a paycheck, so this is a great idea.
But, there wasn't really the money to actually,
you know, even have one employee, at that time.
There was a fellow, Squamish climber named Nick Jones
who was the, working at rock solid at the time when it was just chalk
bags and quick draws and slings, mostly Bartok stuff right into.
So Dave was working as a carpenter during the day to make money
to keep rock solid alive.
And then Nick would be working in the garage, making the,
making the small slings and things like that. So,
not long after, Dave met Jeremy and,
they started to put the whole story of Arc'teryx together.
So, you know, very quickly the name Arc'teryx was created, and,
I got another phone call from Dave Lane asking to come and join.
And I said, well, I hear there's a businessman involved now.
So, I said, yeah, for sure.
Come on over.
And, that was the first little,
factory at 1440 Columbia Street in North End,
which is, you know, less than 1000m from our headquarters.
Right now on the other side of the bridge.
So, yeah, that was the that was the very beginning.
And I remember walking in there
and, you know, there was maybe 5 or 6 people
that was the entire company in one small room.
So you were designing some, like climbing gears and then two
when you.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
In the 1980s, I had my own little label, and,
I didn't think making harnesses was a good idea
because I wouldn't be able to get them certified and,
and, and, and made to the best standard.
So I kept to stuff that was,
somewhat less technical and that,
that also made me realize that that stuff that I was making
had to look better and had to be better, or else
why would you do it
if you were going to make something that was the same as everybody else's?
Well, maybe that's a little bit of a business.
I, I think there's a, there always is
and always was a bigger creative opportunity to make things.
Not just better, but, you know, more beautiful had having having something
that, made people care that that effort was made
that you that you didn't just make a, a functional,
simple thing, you made something that was enchanting.
And, you would you would you would you would have some love for it
or respect for it because the people that made it and designed
it had a love for it and respect for it as well.
And you could see that with our work, you could see that we take care.
